title-group.article-title: Stabilization of all-pole unstable delay systems by fractional-order [PI] and [PD] controllers

contrib-group.aff: Electrical Engineering Department, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: A Jalali, Electrical Engineering Department, Iran University of Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran Email: drjalali@iust.ac.ir

abstract.p: The stabilization of all-pole unstable systems with time delay by fractional-order controllers is investigated in this paper. Sufficient conditions for stabilizability by fractional-order [PD]/[PI] controllers are determined. To derive the conditions for stability, an analysis based on Nyquist stability criterion is adopted and the upper bound for the time delay is determined. Furthermore, this paper provides the stabilizing range of the controller parameters. Theoretical proofs in company with illustrative examples are also provided.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Instability caused by time delay is a common phenomenon in process control (Normey-Rico and Camacho, 2007). Numerous methods have been introduced to reduce the effects of time delay in order to obtain a stabilized process. However, when the plant has an unstable pole, the effects of time delay have to be taken into account along with the impact of the unstable pole on the stability of the closed-loop system. Proportional–integral–derivative (PID) controllers and their special cases have been very popular in industrial control, owing to the fact that they can be easily tuned to get the perfect performance. In spite of numerous tuning algorithms and wide range of application for PID controllers in industry, some conditions must be satisfied when they are applied to unstable processes with time delay. To derive such limitations, analysing the stabilizability of unstable delay processes is the first step in control system design. There have been attempts to tackle the problem of stabilizability of time-delay systems. Hwang and Chen (1997) used a root locus method to study the stabilizability of unstable delay processes by PI/PD controllers and have proposed an upper limit for time delay as a condition for stabilizability. Xiang et al. (2007) utilized a Nyquist stability criterion to find the upper bound of the time delay and the stabilizing range for the controller parameters. The studied controllers in Xiang et al. (2007) are simple integer-order P, PI, PD and PID controllers. The stabilization of unstable delay systems with zero dynamics has also been investigated in Lee et al. (2010a) and Lee and Wang (2010). The stabilizability conditions are obtained for the cases that the controllers are conventional integer-order controllers. Wang (2009) has proposed the stabilizing set of PID parameters for all-pole time-delay systems based on the Hermite–Beihler theorem. The stabilization of all-pole delay systems with a single unstable pole has been studied in Lee et al. (2010b) where the results obtained in Xiang et al. (2007) are extended to establish the stabilizability conditions for all-pole delay systems.

In recent years, fractional-order systems and controllers have attracted considerable attention. This is because many processes can be described by fractional-order differential equations. Fractional-order controllers, which are based on fractional calculus, have some extra degrees of freedom, which make it possible to design control systems with better performance. Podlubny (1999a) has proposed fractional-order PID (FOPID) controllers that are denoted by PIλDμ. The transfer function of an FOPID is in the form of KP(1+KDsμ+KIsλ) where μ and λ, the orders of the derivative and integral, can be non-integer. It has been demonstrated that FOPID controllers enhance the performance and robustness of control systems (Birbil et al., 2004; Ladaci et al., 2008). Padula and Visioli (2011) have shown that the use of fractional-order derivative action improves the performance of a control system in set-point following and load disturbance rejection tasks. Lee and Chang (2010) have also shown the better performance of the FOPID controller in comparison with the integer-order PID controller. A control system with the fractional-order controllers is robust to loop gain changes (Barbosa et al., 2004; Monje et al., 2004). Zamani et al. (2009) have shown that the FOPID is more robust than the conventional integer-order PID with respect to model uncertainties. A fractional-order proportional derivative PDμ controller (FOPD), which is a specific form of PIλDμ controller in which the order of the integrator λ is zero, has been addressed in the literature. Zhuang et al. (2006) have proposed a PDμ controller to enhance the performance of a driver–vehicle system. Li et al. (2010) have proposed a tuning algorithm of FOPD controllers for a class of second-order stable plants. Luo and Chen (2009) have proposed fractional-order [proportional derivative] controllers (FO-[PD]), which can be represented by the transfer function model of KP(1+KDs)μ. By comparing the simulation results of this type of controller with integer-order PID and also an FOPD controller, it has been illustrated that the FO-[PD] results in a better performance of the closed-loop system. In addition, Luo and Chen (2009) have shown that the standard PID controller may not always be stabilizing to achieve flat-phase specification, whereas both FOPD and FO-[PD] controllers are always stabilizing. Fractional-order [proportional integral] controllers (FO-[PI]) have also attracted attention in the past few years. They are represented by KP(1+KIs)λ. Tuning of these controllers in many cases is easier than that of fractional-order proportional integral PIλ controllers (FOPI). They also have a better time response. Luo et al. (2010) have designed an FOPI, an FO-[PI] and a standard integer-order PID (IOPID) controller based on the same tuning constraints. Through simulations and experimental results, it has been illustrated that fractional-order controllers outperform the integer-order ones. By comparing fractional-order FOPI and FO-[PI] controllers, it is observed that better performance can be achieved by using the FO-[PI] controllers. Generally, the control effort of an FO-[PI] controller is smaller than that of an FOPI controller (Luo et al., 2010). Fractional-order controllers have been used for stabilization of time-delay systems. Caponetto et al. (2010) have determined the complete set of stabilizing PIλDμ parameters. Using a version of the Hermite–Biehler theorem, Caponetto et al. (2010) have designed a fractional-order controller to stabilize a first-order plant with time delay. Hamamci and Koksal (2010) have proposed all stabilizing PDμ controllers for integrating time-delay systems. Their algorithm is based on the results of stability boundary locus method.

The main contribution of this paper is establishing the stabilizability criteria by fractional-order [PD] and [PI] controllers when they are applied to all-pole unstable delay systems. Our purpose is to derive sufficient conditions for stability. In addition, we present the stabilizing ranges of the controller parameters. The approach is based on the Nyquist stability criterion. The rest of the paper is organized as follows. In the next section, a brief overview of fractional-order control is given and FO-[PI] and FO-[PD] controllers are introduced, followed by the preliminaries. Then the main results are presented and some numerical examples are given, followed by the conclusions.

sec.title: Fractional calculus and fractional control
sec.p: Fractional calculus has been used as a mathematical tool for modelling physical systems and designing controllers. Fractional calculus is an extension of integer-order calculus in which ordinary differential equations have been replaced by fractional-order differential equations. In fractional-order differential equations, derivatives and integrals are not necessarily of integer order and they span a wider range of differential equations.

sec.title: Fractional-order [proportional integral] and [proportional derivative] controllers
sec.p: The fractional-order [Proportional Integral] (FO-[PI]) and [Proportional Derivative] (FO-[PD]) controllers are two types of fractional-order controllers proposed in literature (Luo and Chen, 2009; Luo et al., 2010). The transfer function of an FO-[PI] is given by

Also, the transfer function in Equation (6) is characterized by three parameters: the proportional gain KP, the integral gain KI and the fractional order λ that belongs to range (0,2). By applying the fractional controllers, some extra parameters are available that can be tuned to obtain a better performance. These controllers retain the main characteristics of the integer-order controllers while they span a wider range of controllers; For instance, an FO-[PI] changes from a P to a PI as the order of the controller changes from 0 to 1. This feature makes it possible to design a controller that can have the advantages of both P and PI with a tunable weight, which affects the performance of the controller.

According to Nyquist stability criterion, for closed-loop stability of the system, the Nyquist plot of the open-loop system must encircle the critical point (−1,0) once anticlockwise. Based on Nyquist criterion, it can be shown that a necessary condition on the open-loop transfer function Q(s) for closed-loop stability is as follows (Xiang et al., 2007).

Since there is a time-delay element in the open-loop transfer function, the phase of Q(jω) tends to −∞ when ω→∞. This will lead to infinite encirclements of the critical point clockwise, and the closed-loop system will be unstable (for more details, see Lemma 2 in Xiang et al., 2007). Hence, one part of the Nyquist curve begins at (+∞,0) and ends at Q(j∞) and the other symmetrical part begins from Q(−j∞) and ends at (+∞,0). This means the Nyquist curve encircles the critical point (−1,0) an even number of times, and consequently the closed-loop system cannot be stable for K>0. Therefore K<0 is a necessary condition for the stability of the closed-loop system. □

sec.p: In order to simulate the step response of transfer functions involving fractional orders of s, the Oustaloup method (Oustaloup et al., 2000) has been used to find a rational continuous approximation of the fractional transfer function of the controller using a number of poles and zeros (N), which is valid in a frequency range. The number of poles and zeros of the approximated transfer function (N) and the frequency range ([ωl,ωh]) are selected in advance.

The lower values of N result in simpler models; however, ripples appear both in gain and phase plots. Such ripples would disappear by increasing N in the expense of having computationally more complex models. In this paper, to approximate the FO-[PI] controller, N=7 and frequency bounds are selected as ωl=0.0001 and ωh=KI=0.2 The step response of the closed-loop system is depicted in Figure 3. The frequency response of the stabilized plant is also shown in Figure 4.

sec.title: Example 3
sec.p: The results of Theorem 2 are used to design a stabilizing FO-[PD] controller for the high-order process model of G¯(s)=e−0.1s(2s−1)(0.2s+1)3, which was studied by Kwak et al. (2000). The order of the FO-[PD] controller is assumed to be μ=0.6. For normalization of the process model, we use the technique presented in the ‘Problem statement and preliminaries’ section and obtain G(s)=e−0.05s(s−1)(0.1s+1)3. The normalized time constants are Ti=0.1,i=1,2,3. Since L=0.05<1−∑i=13Ti+μ(1+∑i=1nTi2)=1.4861, the stabilizability condition (31) holds. From Equation (33) the stabilizing range for KD is −1.0833<KD<1.3102. Let KD=0.18. Then the crossover frequency is obtained from ϕ(ω)=−0.05ωc−3arctan(0.1ωc)+arctan(ωc)+0.6arctan(0.18ωc)−π=−π, which gives ωc=5.89. According to Equation (34), the stabilizing range for KP is 1<KP<7.45. With KP=2, the FO-[PD] controller will be C(s)=2(1+0.18s)0.6, which leads to C¯(s)=2(1+0.26s)0.6. The Nyquist plot of C¯(s)G¯(s) is given in Figure 10. For this process, the controller parameters of the standard PID controller tuned by the modified Ziegler–Nichols tuning rule1 are given as in Kwak et al. (2000): Kp=1.6001, τi=3.4261 and τd=0.7064. By placing the FO-[PD] in the feedback path, the step responses of the FO-[PD] and the conventional integer-order PID are given in Figure 11, and show that the proposed fractional-order controller gives a superior performance in set point tracking.

sec.title: Example 4
sec.p: We consider the stabilization of G(s)=e−0.1s(s−1)(0.4s+1)(0.1s+1), which was studied by Lee et al. (2010b). A PI controller has been designed for this process, where KI=0.05. The stabilizing range for KP has been obtained as (1.070, 2.997). Then for KP=3.05, the process is not stabilized. Figure 12 shows the Nyquist plot of the process with the PI controller 3.05(1+0.05s). Now we illustrate the role of the fractional order μ in stabilization of the process. The order of the FO-[PI] controller is assumed to be λ=0.5. Figure 13 shows the Nyquist plot of the process with the FO-[PI] controller 3.05(1+0.05s)0.5. It is observed that the process can be stabilized when the order of the controller is non-integer. From Equation (29), the stabilizing range for KP is obtained as (1.0280, 3.0941).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, the stabilizability of all-pole delay systems with an unstable pole by means of fractional-order [PI] and [PD] controllers has been studied. It has been shown that both [PI] and [PD] controllers are able to stabilize the unstable delay process under the conditions presented in Theorems 1 and 2. These conditions have been established in terms of maximum allowable time delay and the acceptable ranges for the controller parameters. The results are straightforward for control system design in industrial processes.
